title: What is your favorite Rap song? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the A2A, this is a tough question to answer. I'm going to answer it, but i need you to take this serious and check them out. I'm gonna kick it off with the illest verse that ever graced the ears of Hiphop: “’98 Freestyle” - Big L : this song appears on the album “The Big Picture”; which I'm sure everyone knows, but, if they don't, they need to know right now. I mean, right now!! Leave this page, do not continue on, GO!! It also can be found under the titles “’98 Freestyle, parts I & II” that contains a verse, and you can even find some versions with the full interview and everything from the Stretch Bobbito show. Whatever the case, get this, listen to it.“Chest 2 Chest Freestyle” - The Lox : this originally appeared on DJ Clue’s “Show Me the Money” mixtape from 1997. The song title appeared as simply “Freestlyle”, as most songs on DJ Clue tapes (a fact that would lead to much frustration as I moved to digital media), but I wrote “Chest 2 Chest” because that's how it most commonly appears, because in the beginning they say “L-O-X chest to chest, back to back, glock to glock, Mack to mack…” it is likewise simply titled “L.O.X. Freestyle” or even “Clue Freestyle”. Whatever the case it's basically a Freestyle on that “Next Level (Nyte Time Mix)” which is on Showbiz & AG’s album “Goodfellas”, which is a DJ Premier beat also. Anyway, Jada’s verse is so trill.“Envy” - Fat Joe : Samples Marvin Gaye’s hit “Sexual Healing”, and this song is my life, save a few minor details such as location, names, and titles. Other than that, it is me I plan to sue.“Can It Be All So Simple (remix)” - Raekwon : feat. Ghostface Killah, who just wrecked it. Went bonkers. The thing I always wondered too, is, how true the lyrics are because he really did get shot in the neck.“Everyday Struggle” - The Notorious B.I.G.“City Under Siege” - The Get Boys : third verse especially.“Gettin’ It” - Too Short : if you can't appreciate this song, this flow, you ain't Hiphop. Give it up. This is the best, trillest even positive record.“Oh My Darling” - Run the JewelsCocaine in the Back of the Ride” - UGK“Still a Nigga” - Eazy-E“Str8 Ballin” 2Pac“Nuthin But a ‘G’ Thang” - Dr. Dre : no one said this yet? What are you guys smoking? Not Chronic.“Regular Cat” - Memphis Bleek“All Money In” - Nipsey Hussle“Loves Gonna Get’cha” - Boogie Down Productions“Build & Destroy” - Boogie Down Productions“Rapper’s Delight” - Sugarhill Gang : if you like Hiphop, you like this song. I'm sorry. A lot of hiphoppas I know will not admit it, because they're “too cool” or whatever, but they're lying. They love this song.“Memory Lane” - Nas“One Time 4 Your Mind” - Nas“Give Up the Goods (Just Step)” - Mobb Deep“Can't Truss It” - Public Enemy“If I Get Locked Up Tonight” - Eminem : This is actually a Funkmaster Flex & Big Kap track came out on “The Tunnel”, but it features Eminem and Dr. Dre.“Fubba U Cubba Freestyle” - Eminem : this is a piece of a Freestyle, usually titled as it appears in my entry, and the first time I heard it was on DJ Greenlantern’s “Anger Management Tour Mixtape”, but I've seen it titled differently elsewhere. It was actually a Freestyle from a Tim Westwood show over the “Got It Twisted” by Mobb Deep beat, but there is actually a whole song where all D12 rips, and its dope, I recommend that version. Kuniva is one of the most underrated, Proof (RIP) was too. I think they're underrated because they rap with Em.“Desperadoes” - The Firm“Heat Wave” - Chris Rivers“Dreams & Nightmares (Intro)” - Meek Mill“Fuck Martinez” - 2 Live Crew :This is my last and final entry, it may be better to do albums next time, but these are some of the illest verses in Hiphop history, I know there are many more of equal caliber. The last entry, of course, was on Uncle Luke’s first solo album, but the also released it under 2 Live Crew with another album cover change; however, both are the same album, both titled “Banned in the U.S.A.” However, I put this on the list, even though it lacks the lyrical presence as the other songs because the history makes the song so ill, and so classic. This was the album they released in the famous Supreme Court case, requiring rappers to put the “Parental Advisory” stickers on the album covers. The story goes: Bob Martinez, Florida governor had Navarro (the album also features a song called “Fuck Navarro”) arrest 2 Live Crew related to the contents of their music, and tried to ban all of their music and shows from Florida. So, they dropped “Banned in the U.S.A.” which, of course features the above mentioned song, where it's a bass dance-club type record with Luke yelling, “Fuck Martinez, Fuck, Fuck, Marteen-ez” the whole song. It's epic. It just embodies the Hiphop message and Hiphop philosophy. I love listening to it, gives me a sense of sheer pleasure.

JAY-Z - 99 Problems (sorry about the censoring)Enough said really. Iconic hook, great storytelling, rhymes and flow. When I was young it was all my dad used to play in the car, so naturally I grew attached. 2. Jay Z ft. Rihanna & Kanye West - Run This Town (sorry about the live version) This was on repeat all the time when I was young on my MP3 player. My childhood anthem, not to mention the amazing features and the chemistry they have. 3. Kanye West - Homecoming (sorry about the censoring) The best song on Graduation, and in my opinion Kanye’s greatest song. A song that combines cool song elements and a great instrumental. I challenge you to not sing a long to Chris Martin’s chorus. 4. Asher Roth - I Love College (sorry for the censoring) I know, I know, I can hear all you hip hop heads sharpening your pitchforks. Me and my best friend really love this song. We learnt all the lyrics in a night, and while not a lyrically groundbreaking song, it’s a really fun and chill song. It’s also what got me into Asher Roth. 5. Kanye West - So Appalled (feat. Jay-Z, CyHi Da Prynce & Pusha T) (sorry about the audio) In my opinion, the best multi feature/cypher rap song post 2000. The word play and lyricism is phenomenal. There isn’t a weak verse, and the beat and flows just work so well. My favourite song on MBDTF. 6. Jay-Z - A Dream (feat. Faith Evans & The Notorious B.I.G.) (there’s no youtube video or audio where I searched) A nice tribute song and a cool use of a sample. Also, I really like how Jay made it sound so good despite rhyming ‘I said’ with ‘I said’ about 20 times over. Also, when I was young, my dad played the shit out of this song. He was a big Jay-Z fan. 7. Coolio - Gangsta's Paradise feat. L.V. Not much to say. Probably the most recognizable song in rap and hip hop. Everything about it is just good, and very real. Coolio’s underrated. 8. Outkast - Ms Jackson Another ballad from my childhood. It’s just so catchy. It’s a great song that is just the ultimate nostalgia trip. 9. Biz Markie - Just A Friend I challenge you to not sing, hum or belt out the chorus in your head. The ultimate karaoke song, party song and all round just fun song. 10. Kid Cudi - Day 'N' Nite A cool, groovy song that has a really cool vibe to it. Great song to get high to. Alternative 10. Kanye West - Stronger Day N Nite is more singing than rapping, so I included an alternative if you thought that too. Stronger is in my top 3 Kanye songs. It’s motivational and hype, yet very cool and chill if you want it to be. Great lyrics too.

Honestly, life is good by Drake has nice beats but my favourite lyrics in a rap song are in Reagan by Killer Mike Reagan - Killer Mike : The song begins with the registration of 40th US president Ronald Reagan, that during the second half of the 1980s was involved in the so-called Irangate, the Iran-Contra affair. The Reagan administration sold arms to Iran, who was fighting against Iraq, in exchange for its influence in releasing American hostages held in Lebanon, and the profits of the trade financed the militant group Contras in Nicaragua. Killer Mike uses the character, Reagan, to shout out against both the government and the rap industry corruption, “Ronald Reagan was an actor. He was a pitchman at first, and so people naturally trust him. He understood how to weave magic when he was speaking, and that’s what we as entertainers do. So when Jay-Z tells you to buy some Reeboks, it means more. Ronald Reagan at one point was the biggest pitchman in the world. I think that Reagan was used by a political party, by people who had vested means, to push their own agendas. He had his own agendas, and I think that no rapper had ever said, ‘I’ve been guilty of this. I have hurt my community as a rapper.'” He uses the personality as a way to open people’s eyes in front of a reality that is not always easy to accept, as it’s underlined in the lyrics of the song “Just another talking head telling lies on teleprompters”. One of the issues contained in the song concerns the war on drugs in the US that has produced profoundly unequal outcomes across racial groups (“They declared the war on drugs like a war on terror/But it really did was let the police terrorize whoever”), targeting African Americans and Latinos, because of their association with urban and lower-income communities, and therefore most likely to become drug addicts. Killer Mike complains about the abuse of the criminal justice system towards marginalised communities on the basis of racial discrimination (“But mostly black boys, but they would call us “niggers”/And lay us on our belly, while they fingers on they triggers”). Overall “Reagan” depicts a cruel but sadly honest picture of the reality of today, and the author’s intent is to point out a social issue rather than a political one, as he pointed out in an interview to National Public Radio (NPR).

As always when it comes to music I’m unable to pick one favourite song from a genre. But I will happily share with you my various favourite rap songs! First up there’s a few oldies… The Sugarhill Gang - Rappers Delight  Run DMC - It’s Like That  Coolio - Gangsters Paradise  Then there’s some from post 2000… Eminem - The Way I Am  Sean Paul - Like Glue  Rizzle Kicks - Mama Do The Hump  Then there’s my favourites from music that my boyfriend introduced me to… JuJu D - Me & You  Krazie K - If I Told You  El Chojin - Rap vs Racismo  What can I say, I’ve lived enough years & love so much music that it’s impossible for me to pick just one favourite rap song. But at least I did manage to get it down to 9 favourite rap tunes, which is miraculous for me ;-) (Videos courtesy of YouTube).

Digable Planets : Black Ego The intro / skit is pretty long and, frankly, boring … just jazzy widdling … But hold in there … with the volume up … because that moment Mecca, the Ladybug comes in on the first verse is one of the most chillingly beautiful and spine-tingling moments in any piece of music , in any genre, ever.  The first time I heard this (I’d just bought the tape and was listening to it on headphones) I literally had an eargasm at hearing Mecca’s mix of ASMR intimacy and black radical self-confidence; all set against that weird desolate cosmic backdrop that makes you feel you’re watching nebulae dancing at the heart of the universe. And then when the drums hit 12 seconds later I was (metaphorically) spurting all over the place. (Apologies for the imagery, but I have a point to make here, people.) Then it gets boring again … why do they love that jazzy guitar riff so much? It gets pretty good again when doodlebug and butterfly do their thing over the verse music. Then the playout it execrable. Unless you like some dude actually doing live jazzy widdling for about 3 unnecessary minutes. (Sorry jazzy guitar dude, I had a friend who loved that part, it just wasn’t for me.) But, really, it’s Mecca’s first verse which is one of the most sublime, perfect 40 seconds of music ever created by human (or insect) kind.

It is a very hard question to answer as I am drawing a thin line between living in Old School rap and New School rap. Old SchoolOne of my personal favorites is C.R.E.A.M by Wu-Tang because of its influential lyrics. I also appreciate Yoke the joker by Naughty by Nature. The albums “Me Against The World” from Tupac and “Slim Shady EP” by Eminem are also something I crave for all the time.New SchoolWell, many.. There are many new school rappers who’re rocking it right now. From Kendrick’s Damn to Logic’s Everybody. Chance the rapper’s Acid Rap to J. Cole’s 4 Your Eyez Only. These are all some legit rap albums from new school in recent times. Most of the songs are deeply felt and exist in the deepest veins of my heart. Actually, it is pretty difficult for me to answer your question because my preference to a rap song changes rapidly as new songs keep coming up or I reminisce the old songs they become the favorite. again.As for this instance, I love hearing Molly by Lil dicky ft. Brendon Urie on repeat, but it may change after some time.

You Were My Everything by Aviation: The starting intro and BAM, right in the feels! This goes out to someone that wasOnce the most important person in my lifeI didn’t realize it at the timeI can’t forgive myself for the way I treated you soI don’t really expect you to eitherIt’s just... I don’t even knowJust listen… Some lines sounds like poetry which fulfills the purpose of RAP, as it is an acronym for Rhythm And Poetry! When I first saw you, I knew it was realI’m sorry about the pain I made you feel That wasn’t me; let me show you the wayI looked for the sun, but it’s raining todayI remember when I first looked into your eyesIt was like God was there, heaven in the skies He is justifying Georgia Cates's quote, "Music is what feelings sound like", perfectly. Tell me if i'm wrong! I knew you gonna sit and play this with your new manAnd then sit and laugh as you’re holding his handThe thought of that just shatters my heartIt breaks in my soul and it tears me apart This song is the strongest, I've been hearing for quite a while (roughly 8 + years) ...just AWESOME!!!! I guess everything you said was a lieI think about it, it brings tears to my eyesNow I’m not even a thought in your mindI can see clearly, my love is not blind This song will make you wanna chop the other person's head off (who is being blamed here).  It has the best lyrics in the world. You said you were my best friend, was that a lie?Now I’m nothing to you, you’re with another guyI tried, I tried, I tried, and I’m tryingNow on the inside it feels like I’m dying And these little talking verses in between and in the end will give you goosebumps for life. It's one of a kind.  And I do miss youI just thought we were meant to beI guess now, we’ll never knowThe only thing I want is for you to be happyWhether it be with me, or without meI just want you to be happy I almost forgot; It also has the most awesome melodious background music ever made in the history of rap music. Period. P.S: I really really want Eminem to do a cover of this song.  Source- AVIATION LYRICS - You Were My Everything

I tend to favor the older rap songs. These days, there is just too much foul language in rap music. They genre tries to stay true to it’s community, where that language is normally spoken, so I understand why. I just don’t enjoy listening to it. And, on radio and tv, the foul language is blocked out, so the songs don’t sound complete when they do that. As per usual, I’m not picking one song, but I can say there is a song that probably is the best one. Jay-Z featuring Alicia Keys homage to New York in “Empire State of Mind” is the best rap song. This was one of the best live performances of the song, at the 2009 Grammy Awards:  Jay-Z’s collaboration with Justin Timberlake in 2013’s “Suit and Tie” was a huge hit for JT, and provided with another great rap performance from Jay-Z:  So, I suppose Jay-Z is my favorite rap artist. A nod to the earlier artists who released cleaner recordings, understanding that they wouldn’t get much radio play if they didn’t. But it was rap music that I appreciated more. Heavy D, Will Smith, and the groundbreaking Sugarhill Gang, who had the first real big rap hits with “Rapper’s Delight” and this little ditty…

As a middle aged white guy, I don’t listen to rap, but one song stands out, and I can listen to it over and over again, probably because it was so fresh. Hard to believe this was 38 years ago. It starts out “I said a hip, hop, a hippie to the hippie The hip, hip a hop, and you don’t stop, a rock it out….” (Rapper’s Delight, by The Sugarhill Gang) Feel old yet?

DISCLAIMER: I am a very recent newcomer to rap (since 2012) and so a large majority of the rap songs I listen to are new-school (if not all of them). My favorite rap song is 151 Rum by J.I.D While J.I.D isn’t my favorite rapper (probably top 15 though) this song is AMAZING.

If I had to choose a couple of my favorites it would be (in no specific order): Numbers by A Boogie wit a Hoodie feat. Gunna and Roddy Ricch.  4 Your Eyez Only-J.Cole  Wassup- Lil Uzi Vert Feat. Future  These are three of my favorite but if I had to choose between these it would be J.Cole because he is an amazing lyricist (so is Kendrick Lemar).

Juicy by Notorious BIG or anything by BIG. I’m a fan of old school r&b and funk I even like some disco, when juicy came out and it sampled Mtune’s song juicy it had all the elements in one record, a old school beat, well put together lyrics, a story told about the struggles of street life that you can actually imagine and see while the song is playing. It was about things that I could relate to in my life guns, drugs, money and women. Taking a negative experience and turning it into a positive. I was never a Tupac fan even to this day, I respect him as an artist and for his contribution to the hip hop culture but I personally just wasn’t a fan of his music other than liking 1 or 2 songs.

My honest to good Answer, I don’t like Rap! I consider this to be one of the worst Forms of Musical Styles ever conceived in the whole History of Music; in fact where is the Music in all of this? Take some of the more Modern Forms of this for example. What do we have, essentially nothing but some so-called Musician; certainly not a Singer giving it a load of sometimes unintelligible blurb; in your face Noise and they give it this arbitrary name of Hip Hop. Yeah right! Who are they honestly trying to kid? Whatever happened to those Wonderful days of the Lead Guitar solo, with those high pitched Chords which drove you Ecstatically Wild? L.L.S.

I live allusic but what I call hard rap. Kid rock started getting my attention with wanna be a cowboy baby and the change he has made within till his music today. I will be honest. It's hard for me to understand rap and the cussing is not for me. I struggle daily with cussing because my family cussess. Ive been told hery have you been at your brothers? I replied, yes how did you know ? They said because you cuss more afterwards. True that. I often feel quilty for being different and I try to fit in with them. Rap music is cussing and babaloin to me. Give me Opera, country, the 80’s, 90’s gospel, bluegrass , blues, jazz, and even rock. But I have no clue r pattern to the beat in hard rap. Don't understand a word of it except cussing. But to each their own
